fields.content:
This page lists all participants in alphabetic order (by first name).  
It also gives each participant's answers to the three questions that were asked during registration.  
Please feel free to modify your entry!


***
#### Adrian Bolboaca


**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Facilitator in several European software comunities, ideas bumble-bee pollinator


**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

can't think of anything


**What do you want to take home from the event?**


good ideas


***
#### Andrea Boriero

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm a member of the London Software Craftsmanship Community

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

https://github.com/dreab8

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

knowldege and friendship


***
#### Andreas Budde

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Yet no relation, I don't know much about the definition.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I don't write a blog or have a public repository.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I hope it's more gainful than huge expensive conferences that degenerate into a promotion.
I want to become acquainted to interesting/experienced people.
I want to share knowledge about concurrency with others. What is the best way to test concurrent code? Is the actor pattern (like introduced in scala) advantages against classical patterns?
Where do the others see more advantages: waterfall or agile developement?
How will programming look like in 10 to 20 years from now?
What are the experiences of others in working abroad as a software engineer?


***
#### Andreas Gnyp

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Recommendation from a colleague.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Maybe a few ideas regarding JavaScript, agile Development. Not sure yet.  In any case my vivid participation. :-)

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas and perspectives. I can imagine this kind of event to produce new ways of doing things. Also it might be very interesting to exchange over problems and topics of the daily work.


***
#### Andreas Leidig

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am infected by the idea that software should represent a "good piece of work". I'm striving to be able to achieve that, to help others achieving that and finding out what is important and what not. Besides I organize events on the topic. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I bring my whole personality with me. I have plenty of experience and opinion. 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ideas, concepts, shared experiences and personal contacts. I hope my horizon will broaden and broaden and broaden and ... 


***
#### Andreas Simon

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Ich bin gerne stolz auf meine Arbeit. Ich bin froh, wenn ich stabilen, wartbaren, gut lesbaren Code produziert habe. Ich habe generell einen sehr hohen Anspruch an meine Arbeit.
Ich lerne andauernd und gerne mehr über TDD, OO Design und agile Methoden. Ich gebe auch gerne mein Wissen - z.B. im Rahmen von Code Retreats - an jüngere Entwickler weiter.
Am Ende der letzten SoCraTes habe ich mich mit Markus Gärtner, Martin Klose und Oliver Paczkowski zusammengetan, um die Regionalgruppe SoCraMOB in der Region Münster, Osnabrück, Bielefeld ins Leben zu rufen. Wir haben mittlerweile zwei ganztägige Open Spaces und drei Code Retreats veranstaltet. Unsere Mitgliederzahl wächst kontinuierlich.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://andreas-simon.blogspot.com  
https://github.com/andreassimon  
Ich entwickle Web-Anwendungen mit Java und Ruby.
Meine Stärken liegen im Strukturieren und Mustersuchen. Ich habe zu vielen Bereichen eine klare Meinung und verfechte sie gerne in angeregten Diskussionen.

Für unsere SC Community habe ich einen Überblick über die Geschichte / Wurzeln von Software Craftsmanship zusammengestellt. Gerne würde ich den Vortrag auch bei der SoCraTes anbieten.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich freue mich darauf, einige "Meister" unseres Faches zu treffen und von ihnen zu lernen.
Insbesondere interessiert mich, wie andere Craftsmen mit Legacy Code umgehen. Außerdem würde ich gerne mehr über Domain-Driven Design lernen: wie wenden andere Teilnehmer die Ideen von DDD in ihren Projekten an?
Ich würde mich auch gerne mit den Organisatoren anderer Communities austauschen, welche Veranstaltungsformate sie durchgeführt haben und wie das Feedback war.
Wenn die SoCraTes nur annähernd so informativ und motivierend wie die letzte Ausgabe wird, bin ich mehr als zufrieden. :-)


***
#### Balint Pato

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am an associate of the London Software Craftsmanship Community

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://balopat.com

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ideas, inspiration, connections 


***
#### Benjamin Eberlei

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am interested in software architecture and was pointed to this event by friends that work at your sponsor Qafoo.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://whitewashing.de/

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I want to discuss and get feedbacks on my ideas regarding software architecture.


***
#### Benjamin Reitzammer

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I've been drawn to the values of Software Craftsmanship for a long time, without explicitly calling it Software Craftsmanship. So when I stumbled across the book Apprenticeship Patterns, with all it's underlying values, it resonated very strongly with me. The people and the values of Software Craftsmanship gave me concrete words for how I wanted to work.

Since then I've organized coderetreats and started the local Software Craftsmanship community in Frankfurt.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I'm [@benjamin](http://twitter.com/benjamin) on twitter.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

The feeling of having shared my experience and having learned from other participants' experience.
Another point is, to say it with Daniel Temme's words, "I'd be curious about other people's experience in getting other people to care about their work.". That's a challenge I've faced quite often already and haven't found an answer yet, that's satisfying for me.


***
#### Bernhard Findeiss

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

That's my every day job. Apart from that, I also try to participate in the community.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

www.if-blog.de/author/bf

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

The certainty, that there really are people out there for whom writing quality software really DOES matter


***

http://carlduevel.net/ http://holisticon.de 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich bin es leid, dass es scheinbar normal ist, Software neu zu entwickeln, weil die alte Version nicht mehr anpassbar oder zu buggy ist. Die aktuelle Ausbildungspraxis finde ich unpassend.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Blog: http://softwareLeid.de

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

***
#### Kore Nordmann

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Github: github.com/kore

Erfahrungen mit QA, Testing, Software-Design im Bereich von PHP (& JS)
und Webentwicklung allgemein trage ich gerne in Diskussionen oder
Vortraegen bei.

Bio:

Kore Nordmann graduated in 2010 with a degree in computer science
(University). He managed and manages different PHP open source projects,
like Arbit, PHPillow, VCS-Wrapper and others. Some of them can be found
on his website, on Ohloh or github. During the last years he presented
on national and international conferences and published several articles
and books. In 2010 he founded the Qafoo GmbH - passion for software
quality - together with Tobias Schlitt and Manuel Pichler, in which he
provides Consulting & Training aiming for better software quality.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Interesse an Qualitaetsmanagement / Testing in anderen Umgebungen (PHP &
JS QA ist unser Beruf).

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

***

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm working as an Agile Consultant, Coach and Mentor with more than ten years of Programming background. In that roleI'm convinced by the importance of Software Craftmanship and Clean Code. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

An impression where the state of the art Software craftmanship movement stands today. A better understanding of developers today and the experience to do coding katas and dojos again. 


***
#### Martin Klose

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm one of the Socrates organizers and one of the Socramob founders. At Socrates 2011 I met other Software Craftsmans from my region. As we were not form the same town,  for that not able to start a community in our respective towns, we joined forces and started Socramob.org - the local Software Craftsmanship community for Münster, Osnabrück and Bielefeld. Our group has 50+ members and we have run a couple events by now. At the moment I'm helping to build the local Software Craftsmanship community in Berlin. I also like to facilitate coderetreats.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

My curiosity for new ideas, my experience with starting a local community and organizing events. 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas, inspiration and meeting other Software Craftsman.

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

It is an important part of my daily work as software developer. I want to raise the awareness on a more holistic view on software development and on quality. Apart from that, I am co-organizer of SoCraTes and co-founder of Softwerkskammer, the German Software Craftsmanship Community.

***

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Organizer and contributor at SoCraMOB

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

twitter.com/gadeshot

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

meeting great people and having fabulous discussions like 2011


***
#### Pierluigi Pugliese

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

As an agile coach supporting organisations implementing agile I believe software craftsmanship is a key aspect in delivering quality software. While I'm too rusty in coding to be a craftsmanship myself, I can at least help the community to grow.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I will be moderating the open space and I will do my best to support an intense flow of communication among the participants. I would also like to discuss what benefit could a software craftsmanship get from individual or team coaching, presenting a few ideas I have about this topic.

When I'm not at conferences, I am coaching teams and companies who want to introduce agile software development.

For more information: http://www.connexxo.com, http://blog.connexxo.com

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas and new developments in the software craftsmanship community, new friends.


***
#### Raphael Ackermann

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I've been interested in Software Craftsmanship for a while. Always happy to find interesting people sharing similar values.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Just moved into new role writing automated acceptance testing. Curious
to see how this focus shift from developer testing to acceptance
testing will play out.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I'd like to exchange thoughts, get new ideas and inspiration.


***
#### René Füger

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

i'm breathing uncle bob's wisdom, am inspired by the pragmatic programmers and think the only way to go fast is to go well. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

knowledge about applying craftsmanship in an embedded environment 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

knowledge and the feeling that there are other people out there who share the same principles .... 


***
#### Roland Jülich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Software Craftsmanship ist aus meiner Sicht der "Oberbegriff" für die Werte, Prinzipien und Methoden professioneller Softwareentwicklung mit dem Ziel kontinuierlich, qualitativ hochwertige Software zu bauen und zu liefern. Die dazu nötigen Skills werden in der Regel erst durch mehrjährige Praxiserfahrung erworben. Vorraussetzung ist allerdings die stetige Bereitschaft sich kritisch mit der eigenen Arbeit auseinanderzusetzen (auch durch Feedback von anderen), sie zu verbessern, sich ständig weiterzubilden und elementare Techniken zu üben.

Vor diesem Hintergrund sehe ich mich als angehenden Software Craftsman, der für die Prinzipien und Werte in ihrer Vielschichtigkeit sensibilisiert ist und gegenwärtig daran arbeitet seine  Methodik auf- und auszubauen um sie in die tägliche Entwicklungsarbeit zu integrieren. Das ist gar nicht immer so einfach... Da ich in dem Zusammenhang stets auf der Suche nach inspirierenden Ideen, Gesprächen und Mentoren bin, möchte ich mit der "Softwerkskammer Hamburg" als Community of Practice, mir und allen die ähnlich denken ein Forum zum gegenseitigen Austausch geben. Ich freue mich immer wenn ich andere dafür begeistern kann sich mit auf diese Reise zu begeben. ;)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Roland Jülich, Consultant bei der Holisticon AG in Hamburg. Ich bin als Berater und Coach im Geschäftsfeld Architektur mit dem Schwerpunkt agiler Entwicklungsmethoden in verschiedenen Projekten im JEE Umfeld tätig. Persönliche Interessen und Schwerpunkte liegen auf Themen wie Clean Code, Test Driven Development und Automatisierung von Akzeptanztests speziell im Bereich der RIA- und Rich-Client-Entwicklung.

Im Bereich akzeptanztestgetriebener Entwicklung könnte ich bei Interesse das Thema Behavior Driven Development mit Cucumber und Selenium im Java Umfeld vorstellen. Als Format wäre sowohl ein klassischer Vortrag aber auch ein Workshop denkbar. Auf jeden Fall suche ich den Austausch mit anderen im Rahmen des Open Space.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Auf jeden Fall fände ich Anregungen und Inspirationen von anderen Craftsman wie bspw. zur Durchführung von Workshops oder Coding Dojos um andere für das Thema zu begeistern als extrem nützlich. Darüberhinaus möchte ich mich bei der Gelegenheit auch mal mit den anderen Softwerkskammer Moderatoren über mögliche Veranstaltungsformate und Inhalte unterhalten.

#### Andreas Simon

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Ich bin gerne stolz auf meine Arbeit. Ich bin froh, wenn ich stabilen, wartbaren, gut lesbaren Code produziert habe. Ich habe generell einen sehr hohen Anspruch an meine Arbeit.
Ich lerne andauernd und gerne mehr über TDD, OO Design und agile Methoden. Ich gebe auch gerne mein Wissen - z.B. im Rahmen von Code Retreats - an jüngere Entwickler weiter.
Am Ende der letzten SoCraTes habe ich mich mit Markus Gärtner, Martin Klose und Oliver Paczkowski zusammengetan, um die Regionalgruppe SoCraMOB in der Region Münster, Osnabrück, Bielefeld ins Leben zu rufen. Wir haben mittlerweile zwei ganztägige Open Spaces und drei Code Retreats veranstaltet. Unsere Mitgliederzahl wächst kontinuierlich.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://andreas-simon.blogspot.com  
https://github.com/andreassimon  
Ich entwickle Web-Anwendungen mit Java und Ruby.
Meine Stärken liegen im Strukturieren und Mustersuchen. Ich habe zu vielen Bereichen eine klare Meinung und verfechte sie gerne in angeregten Diskussionen.

Für unsere SC Community habe ich einen Überblick über die Geschichte / Wurzeln von Software Craftsmanship zusammengestellt. Gerne würde ich den Vortrag auch bei der SoCraTes anbieten.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich freue mich darauf, einige "Meister" unseres Faches zu treffen und von ihnen zu lernen.
Insbesondere interessiert mich, wie andere Craftsmen mit Legacy Code umgehen. Außerdem würde ich gerne mehr über Domain-Driven Design lernen: wie wenden andere Teilnehmer die Ideen von DDD in ihren Projekten an?
Ich würde mich auch gerne mit den Organisatoren anderer Communities austauschen, welche Veranstaltungsformate sie durchgeführt haben und wie das Feedback war.
Wenn die SoCraTes nur annähernd so informativ und motivierend wie die letzte Ausgabe wird, bin ich mehr als zufrieden. :-)

#### Kore Nordmann

Interessiert beobachtend.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Erfahrungen mit QA, Testing, Software-Design im Bereich von PHP (& JS)
und Webentwicklung allgemein trage ich gerne in Diskussionen oder
Vortraegen bei.

Bio:

Kore Nordmann graduated in 2010 with a degree in computer science
(University). He managed and manages different PHP open source projects,
like Arbit, PHPillow, VCS-Wrapper and others. Some of them can be found
on his website, on Ohloh or github. During the last years he presented
on national and international conferences and published several articles
and books. In 2010 he founded the Qafoo GmbH - passion for software
quality - together with Tobias Schlitt and Manuel Pichler, in which he
provides Consulting & Training aiming for better software quality.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Interesse an Qualitaetsmanagement / Testing in anderen Umgebungen (PHP &
JS QA ist unser Beruf).

***
#### Roland Jülich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Software Craftsmanship ist aus meiner Sicht der "Oberbegriff" für die Werte, Prinzipien und Methoden professioneller Softwareentwicklung mit dem Ziel kontinuierlich, qualitativ hochwertige Software zu bauen und zu liefern. Die dazu nötigen Skills werden in der Regel erst durch mehrjährige Praxiserfahrung erworben. Vorraussetzung ist allerdings die stetige Bereitschaft sich kritisch mit der eigenen Arbeit auseinanderzusetzen (auch durch Feedback von anderen), sie zu verbessern, sich ständig weiterzubilden und elementare Techniken zu üben.

Vor diesem Hintergrund sehe ich mich als angehenden Software Craftsman, der für die Prinzipien und Werte in ihrer Vielschichtigkeit sensibilisiert ist und gegenwärtig daran arbeitet seine  Methodik auf- und auszubauen um sie in die tägliche Entwicklungsarbeit zu integrieren. Das ist gar nicht immer so einfach... Da ich in dem Zusammenhang stets auf der Suche nach inspirierenden Ideen, Gesprächen und Mentoren bin, möchte ich mit der "Softwerkskammer Hamburg" als Community of Practice, mir und allen die ähnlich denken ein Forum zum gegenseitigen Austausch geben. Ich freue mich immer wenn ich andere dafür begeistern kann sich mit auf diese Reise zu begeben. ;)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Roland Jülich, Consultant bei der Holisticon AG in Hamburg. Ich bin als Berater und Coach im Geschäftsfeld Architektur mit dem Schwerpunkt agiler Entwicklungsmethoden in verschiedenen Projekten im JEE Umfeld tätig. Persönliche Interessen und Schwerpunkte liegen auf Themen wie Clean Code, Test Driven Development und Automatisierung von Akzeptanztests speziell im Bereich der RIA- und Rich-Client-Entwicklung.

Im Bereich akzeptanztestgetriebener Entwicklung könnte ich bei Interesse das Thema Behavior Driven Development mit Cucumber und Selenium im Java Umfeld vorstellen. Als Format wäre sowohl ein klassischer Vortrag aber auch ein Workshop denkbar. Auf jeden Fall suche ich den Austausch mit anderen im Rahmen des Open Space.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Auf jeden Fall fände ich Anregungen und Inspirationen von anderen Craftsman wie bspw. zur Durchführung von Workshops oder Coding Dojos um andere für das Thema zu begeistern als extrem nützlich. Darüberhinaus möchte ich mich bei der Gelegenheit auch mal mit den anderen Softwerkskammer Moderatoren über mögliche Veranstaltungsformate und Inhalte unterhalten.

This page is used to generate and collect ideas for sessions to be held at SoCraTes 2012. In addition, participants interested in hosting a session can find support of like-minded people to prepare and facilitate the session together.

## How does it work?

*Adding a session*: If you have a session idea please grab the Wiki source code of the template from below, copy it, and add your session to the list at the bottom.   
*Expressing interest in a session*: If you are interested in a session on the list, please add your name to the list of interested people of this session. Please also think about how you could contribute and put your contribution in parentheses after your name.



---

## Template

#### Session Title

Session Description ...

*Session host:* YOUR NAME HERE   
*Interested*: ...

---

## Session Ideas

#### Online Mentorenbörse

Kann eine online Mentorenbörse funktionieren? Wie könnte sie aussehen?

*Session host:* Johannes S. (@Ookami86) / Christoph Pater (@christophpater)   
*Interested*: ...

---

#### Intro to Smalltalk

A close look at Smalltalk (the programming language, that is ;-) . You can get an IDE here: http://www.pharo-project.org/home.

*Session host:* Andreas Simon, Andreas Leidig  
*Interested*: Nicole Rauch, Marc Philipp

---

#### Architectural Katas

I find Ted Neward's [Architectural Katas](http://www.architecturalkatas.com/) idea quite intriguing, and would like to try (at least) one with other participants. I haven't done an Architectural Kata yet, so it's not a "I share experience with you" session, but rather a "let's work out the experience together" session.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater, Marc Philipp, Andreas Leidig, Johannes Seitz

---

#### How to do apprenticeship programs?

What are good practices for appentriceship programs in your company/team? How do you get developers (experienced and less experienced) up to speed and productive quickly? What are possible hard- and soft-skills, that are central to being a software craftsman?  
Again, this is a session, which is meant for discussing and elaborating on the topic together.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater

---

#### Organizing Craftsman Swaps (not only) in Germany

Craftsman Swaps are one of the basic practices of Software Craftsmanship. But when I looked around, I really found it hard to find an interested partner: The corresponding [Google Map](http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?ie=UTF8&msa=0&msid=114087136685923801422.0004934ba5dbdca195ead&ll=46.55886,6.679688&spn=112.308024,315.703125&z=2#bmb=1) as well as the [Google Spreadsheat](http://bitly.com/nCbncf) don't seem to really be alive and don't feature as many interested people as I'd hoped.
Therefore I'd like to gather an interested group of people and try to get some life into this!

I'm not sure if this needs to be organized as a session. It could also be e.g. an ongoing effort somewhere in the bar etc.

*Session host:* Bernhard Findeiss   
*Interested*: Benjamin Reitzammer

---

#### Schuldenberater für "insolvente" Softwareprojekte

Ich bin es Leid immer wieder Software von vorne zu beginnen nur weil die techn. Schulden zu hoch geworden sind. Wenn es techn. Schulden gibt, warum dann nicht auch einen techn. Schuldenberater?  Was sollte der tun? Welche Werkzeuge hat er im Gepäck? (Siehe auch: http://www.softwareleid.de/2012/04/hilfe-fur-insolvente-softwareprojekte.html zu der Idee).

*Session host:* Christoph Pater  
*Interested*: ...

---


#### Intro to Objective-C

A long time ago, I tried to get acquainted with Objective-C, but I found the syntax so strange that I could not make any sense of it. Is there anybody willing to help me take the first steps into this language?

*Session host:* Nicole Rauch   
*Interested*: Johannes Seitz (Coding Obj-C for a living), Andreas Leidig

I find Ted Neward's [Architectural Katas](http://www.architecturalkatas.com/) idea quite intriguing, and would like to try (at least) one with other participants. I haven't done an Architectural Kata yet, so it's not a "I share experience with you" session, but rather a "let's work out the experience together" session.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater, Marc Philipp, Andreas Leidig

---

#### How to do apprenticeship programs?

What are good practices for appentriceship programs in your company/team? How do you get developers (experienced and less experienced) up to speed and productive quickly? What are possible hard- and soft-skills, that are central to being a software craftsman?  
Again, this is a session, which is meant for discussing and elaborating on the topic together.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater

---

#### Organizing Craftsman Swaps (not only) in Germany

Craftsman Swaps are one of the basic practices of Software Craftsmanship. But when I looked around, I really found it hard to find an interested partner: The corresponding [Google Map](http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?ie=UTF8&msa=0&msid=114087136685923801422.0004934ba5dbdca195ead&ll=46.55886,6.679688&spn=112.308024,315.703125&z=2#bmb=1) as well as the [Google Spreadsheat](http://bitly.com/nCbncf) don't seem to really be alive and don't feature as many interested people as I'd hoped.
Therefore I'd like to gather an interested group of people and try to get some life into this!

I'm not sure if this needs to be organized as a session. It could also be e.g. an ongoing effort somewhere in the bar etc.

*Session host:* Bernhard Findeiss   
*Interested*: Benjamin Reitzammer

---

#### Schuldenberater für "insolvente" Softwareprojekte

Ich bin es Leid immer wieder Software von vorne zu beginnen nur weil die techn. Schulden zu hoch geworden sind. Wenn es techn. Schulden gibt, warum dann nicht auch einen techn. Schuldenberater?  Was sollte der tun? Welche Werkzeuge hat er im Gepäck? (Siehe auch: http://www.softwareleid.de/2012/04/hilfe-fur-insolvente-softwareprojekte.html zu der Idee).

*Session host:* Christoph Pater  
*Interested*: ...

---


#### Intro to Objective-C

A long time ago, I tried to get acquainted with Objective-C, but I found the syntax so strange that I could not make any sense of it. Is there anybody willing to help me take the first steps into this language?

*Session host:* Nicole Rauch   
*Interested*: ...

#### Andreas Simon

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Ich bin gerne stolz auf meine Arbeit. Ich bin froh, wenn ich stabilen, wartbaren, gut lesbaren Code produziert habe. Ich habe generell einen sehr hohen Anspruch an meine Arbeit.
Ich lerne andauernd und gerne mehr über TDD, OO Design und agile Methoden. Ich gebe auch gerne mein Wissen - z.B. im Rahmen von Code Retreats - an jüngere Entwickler weiter.
Am Ende der letzten SoCraTes habe ich mich mit Markus Gärtner, Martin Klose und Oliver Paczkowski zusammengetan, um die Regionalgruppe SoCraMOB in der Region Münster, Osnabrück, Bielefeld ins Leben zu rufen. Wir haben mittlerweile zwei ganztägige Open Spaces und drei Code Retreats veranstaltet. Unsere Mitgliederzahl wächst kontinuierlich.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://andreas-simon.blogspot.com  
https://github.com/andreassimon  
Ich entwickle Web-Anwendungen mit Java und Ruby.
Meine Stärken liegen im Strukturieren und Mustersuchen. Ich habe zu vielen Bereichen eine klare Meinung und verfechte sie gerne in angeregten Diskussionen.

Für unsere SC Community habe ich einen Überblick über die Geschichte / Wurzeln von Software Craftsmanship zusammengestellt. Gerne würde ich den Vortrag auch bei der SoCraTes anbieten.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich freue mich darauf, einige "Meister" unseres Faches zu treffen und von ihnen zu lernen.
Insbesondere interessiert mich, wie andere Craftsmen mit Legacy Code umgehen. Außerdem würde ich gerne mehr über Domain-Driven Design lernen: wie wenden andere Teilnehmer die Ideen von DDD in ihren Projekten an?
Ich würde mich auch gerne mit den Organisatoren anderer Communities austauschen, welche Veranstaltungsformate sie durchgeführt haben und wie das Feedback war.
Wenn die SoCraTes nur annähernd so informativ und motivierend wie die letzte Ausgabe wird, bin ich mehr als zufrieden. :-)

#### Benjamin Reitzammer

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

The feeling of having shared my experience and having learned from other participants' experience.
Another point is, to say it with Daniel Temme's words, "I'd be curious about other people's experience in getting other people to care about their work.". That's a challenge I've faced quite often already and haven't found an answer yet, that's satisfying for me.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I'd like to exchange thoughts, get new ideas and inspiration.


***
#### René Füger

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

i'm breathing uncle bob's wisdom, am inspired by the pragmatic programmers and think the only way to go fast is to go well. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

knowledge about applying craftsmanship in an embedded environment 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

knowledge and the feeling that there are other people out there who share the same principles .... 


***
#### Roland Jülich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Software Craftsmanship ist aus meiner Sicht der "Oberbegriff" für die Werte, Prinzipien und Methoden professioneller Softwareentwicklung mit dem Ziel kontinuierlich, qualitativ hochwertige Software zu bauen und zu liefern. Die dazu nötigen Skills werden in der Regel erst durch mehrjährige Praxiserfahrung erworben. Vorraussetzung ist allerdings die stetige Bereitschaft sich kritisch mit der eigenen Arbeit auseinanderzusetzen (auch durch Feedback von anderen), sie zu verbessern, sich ständig weiterzubilden und elementare Techniken zu üben.

Vor diesem Hintergrund sehe ich mich als angehenden Software Craftsman, der für die Prinzipien und Werte in ihrer Vielschichtigkeit sensibilisiert ist und gegenwärtig daran arbeitet seine  Methodik auf- und auszubauen um sie in die tägliche Entwicklungsarbeit zu integrieren. Das ist gar nicht immer so einfach... Da ich in dem Zusammenhang stets auf der Suche nach inspirierenden Ideen, Gesprächen und Mentoren bin, möchte ich mit der "Softwerkskammer Hamburg" als Community of Practice, mir und allen die ähnlich denken ein Forum zum gegenseitigen Austausch geben. Ich freue mich immer wenn ich andere dafür begeistern kann sich mit auf diese Reise zu begeben. ;)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Roland Jülich, Consultant bei der Holisticon AG in Hamburg. Ich bin als Berater und Coach im Geschäftsfeld Architektur mit dem Schwerpunkt agiler Entwicklungsmethoden in verschiedenen Projekten im JEE Umfeld tätig. Persönliche Interessen und Schwerpunkte liegen auf Themen wie Clean Code, Test Driven Development und Automatisierung von Akzeptanztests speziell im Bereich der RIA- und Rich-Client-Entwicklung.

Im Bereich akzeptanztestgetriebener Entwicklung könnte ich bei Interesse das Thema Behavior Driven Development mit Cucumber und Selenium im Java Umfeld vorstellen. Als Format wäre sowohl ein klassischer Vortrag aber auch ein Workshop denkbar. Auf jeden Fall suche ich den Austausch mit anderen im Rahmen des Open Space.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Auf jeden Fall fände ich Anregungen und Inspirationen von anderen Craftsman wie bspw. zur Durchführung von Workshops oder Coding Dojos um andere für das Thema zu begeistern als extrem nützlich. Darüberhinaus möchte ich mich bei der Gelegenheit auch mal mit den anderen Softwerkskammer Moderatoren über mögliche Veranstaltungsformate und Inhalte unterhalten.


***
#### Roland Spengler

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

organizational relation - Convinced of a competence approach to develop good software in high quality

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

designed for software quality (DSQ)

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

a lot of new influences for our daily work


***
#### Samir Talwar

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I assist in the organisation of the London Software Craftsmanship Community.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://github.com/samirtalwar is where I put anything interesting.

Ideas and knowledge from other participants

Consider myself craftsman

This page is used to generate and collect ideas for sessions to be held at SoCraTes 2012. In addition, participants interested in hosting a session can find support of like-minded people to prepare and facilitate the session together.

## How does it work?

*Adding a session*: If you have a session idea please grab the Wiki source code of the template from below, copy it, and add your session to the list at the bottom.   
*Expressing interest in a session*: If you are interested in a session on the list, please add your name to the list of interested people of this session. Please also think about how you could contribute and put your contribution in parentheses after your name.



---

## Template

#### Session Title

Session Description ...

*Session host:* YOUR NAME HERE   
*Interested*: ...

---

## Session Ideas

#### Online Mentorenbörse

Kann eine online Mentorenbörse funktionieren? Wie könnte sie aussehen?

*Session host:* Johannes S. (@Ookami86) / Christoph Pater (@christophpater)   
*Interested*: ...

---

#### Intro to Smalltalk

A close look at Smalltalk (the programming language, that is ;-) . You can get an IDE here: http://www.pharo-project.org/home.

*Session host:* Andreas Simon, Andreas Leidig  
*Interested*: Nicole Rauch, Marc Philipp

---

#### Architectural Katas

I find Ted Neward's [Architectural Katas](http://www.architecturalkatas.com/) idea quite intriguing, and would like to try (at least) one with other participants. I haven't done an Architectural Kata yet, so it's not a "I share experience with you" session, but rather a "let's work out the experience together" session.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater, Marc Philipp, Andreas Leidig

---

#### How to do apprenticeship programs?

What are good practices for appentriceship programs in your company/team? How do you get developers (experienced and less experienced) up to speed and productive quickly? What are possible hard- and soft-skills, that are central to being a software craftsman?  
Again, this is a session, which is meant for discussing and elaborating on the topic together.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater

---

#### Organizing Craftsman Swaps (not only) in Germany

Craftsman Swaps are one of the basic practices of Software Craftsmanship. But when I looked around, I really found it hard to find an interested partner: The corresponding [Google Map](http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?ie=UTF8&msa=0&msid=114087136685923801422.0004934ba5dbdca195ead&ll=46.55886,6.679688&spn=112.308024,315.703125&z=2#bmb=1) as well as the [Google Spreadsheat](http://bitly.com/nCbncf) don't seem to really be alive and don't feature as many interested people as I'd hoped.
Therefore I'd like to gather an interested group of people and try to get some life into this!

I'm not sure if this needs to be organized as a session. It could also be e.g. an ongoing effort somewhere in the bar etc.

*Session host:* Bernhard Findeiss   
*Interested*: Benjamin Reitzammer

---

#### Schuldenberater für "insolvente" Softwareprojekte

Ich bin es Leid immer wieder Software von vorne zu beginnen nur weil die techn. Schulden zu hoch geworden sind. Wenn es techn. Schulden gibt, warum dann nicht auch einen techn. Schuldenberater?  Was sollte der tun? Welche Werkzeuge hat er im Gepäck? (Siehe auch: http://www.softwareleid.de/2012/04/hilfe-fur-insolvente-softwareprojekte.html zu der Idee).

*Session host:* Christoph Pater  
*Interested*: ...

**Welcome to the SoCraTes Wiki!**

This wiki can (and should :-) be used by the SoCraTes participants to give the others a little introduction on oneself, to exchange ideas before SoCraTes starts, to arrange for anything that is necessary, and we are curious to see what else you will use it for!

## Important Pages to Start With

- SoCraTesParticipants: This page lists all participants and gives each participant's answers to the three questions that were asked during registration.
- SessionIncubator: This page is used to generate and collect ideas for sessions to be held at SoCraTes 2012. In addition, participants interested in hosting a session can find support of like-minded people to prepare and facilitate the session together.
- CarAndTaxiSharing: Can you offer a space in your car or cab? Are you in need of some means of transportation? Announce it on this page.
- RoomSharing: All of you who are booked in double rooms can search for and find a room mate here

This page is used to generate and collect ideas for sessions to be held at SoCraTes 2012. In addition, participants interested in hosting a session can find support of like-minded people to prepare and facilitate the session together.

## How does it work?

*Adding a session*: If you have a session idea please grab the Wiki source code of the template from below, copy it, and add your session to the list at the bottom.   
*Expressing interest in a session*: If you are interested in a session on the list, please add your name to the list of interested people of this session. Please also think about how you could contribute and put your contribution in parentheses after your name.



---

## Template

#### Session Title

Session Description ...

*Session host:* YOUR NAME HERE   
*Interested*: ...

---

## Session Ideas

#### Online Mentorenbörse

Kann eine online Mentorenbörse funktionieren? Wie könnte sie aussehen?

*Session host:* Johannes S. (@Ookami86) / Christoph Pater (@christophpater)   
*Interested*: ...

---

#### Intro to Smalltalk

A close look at Smalltalk (the programming language, that is ;-)

*Session host:* Andreas Simon, Andreas Leidig  
*Interested*: Nicole Rauch, Marc Philipp

---

#### Architectural Katas

I find Ted Neward's [Architectural Katas](http://www.architecturalkatas.com/) idea quite intriguing, and would like to try (at least) one with other participants. I haven't done an Architectural Kata yet, so it's not a "I share experience with you" session, but rather a "let's work out the experience together" session.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater, Marc Philipp

---

#### How to do apprenticeship programs?

What are good practices for appentriceship programs in your company/team? How do you get developers (experienced and less experienced) up to speed and productive quickly? What are possible hard- and soft-skills, that are central to being a software craftsman?  
Again, this is a session, which is meant for discussing and elaborating on the topic together.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater

fields.content:
This page lists all participants in alphabetic order (by first name).  
It also gives each participant's answers to the three questions that were asked during registration.  
Please feel free to modify your entry!


***
#### Adrian Bolboaca


**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Facilitator in several European software comunities, ideas bumble-bee pollinator


**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

can't think of anything


**What do you want to take home from the event?**


good ideas


***
#### Andrea Boriero

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm a member of the London Software Craftsmanship Community

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

https://github.com/dreab8

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

knowldege and friendship


***
#### Andreas Budde

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**


**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**


**What do you want to take home from the event?**



***
#### Andreas Gnyp

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Recommendation from a colleague.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Maybe a few ideas regarding JavaScript, agile Development. Not sure yet.  In any case my vivid participation. :-)

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas and perspectives. I can imagine this kind of event to produce new ways of doing things. Also it might be very interesting to exchange over problems and topics of the daily work.


***
#### Andreas Leidig

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am infected by the idea that software should represent a "good piece of work". I'm striving to be able to achieve that, to help others achieving that and finding out what is important and what not. Besides I organize events on the topic. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I bring my whole personality with me. I have plenty of experience and opinion. 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ideas, concepts, shared experiences and personal contacts. I hope my horizon will broaden and broaden and broaden and ... 


***
#### Andreas Simon

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Ich bin gerne stolz auf meine Arbeit. Ich bin froh, wenn ich stabilen, wartbaren, gut lesbaren Code produziert habe. Ich habe generell einen sehr hohen Anspruch an meine Arbeit.
Ich lerne andauernd und gerne mehr über TDD, OO Design und agile Methoden. Ich gebe auch gerne mein Wissen - z.B. im Rahmen von Code Retreats - an jüngere Entwickler weiter.
Am Ende der letzten SoCraTes habe ich mich mit Markus Gärtner, Martin Klose und Oliver Paczkowski zusammengetan, um die Regionalgruppe SoCraMOB in der Region Münster, Osnabrück, Bielefeld ins Leben zu rufen. Wir haben mittlerweile zwei ganztägige Open Spaces und drei Code Retreats veranstaltet. Unsere Mitgliederzahl wächst kontinuierlich.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://andreas-simon.blogspot.com  
https://github.com/andreassimon  
Ich entwickle Web-Anwendungen mit Java und Ruby.
Meine Stärken liegen im Strukturieren und Mustersuchen. Ich habe zu vielen Bereichen eine klare Meinung und verfechte sie gerne in angeregten Diskussionen.

Für unsere SC Community habe ich einen Überblick über die Geschichte / Wurzeln von Software Craftsmanship zusammengestellt. Gerne würde ich den Vortrag auch bei der SoCraTes anbieten.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich freue mich darauf, einige "Meister" unseres Faches zu treffen und von ihnen zu lernen.
Insbesondere interessiert mich, wie andere Craftsmen mit Legacy Code umgehen. Außerdem würde ich gerne mehr über Domain-Driven Design lernen: wie wenden andere Teilnehmer die Ideen von DDD in ihren Projekten an?
Ich würde mich auch gerne mit den Organisatoren anderer Communities austauschen, welche Veranstaltungsformate sie durchgeführt haben und wie das Feedback war.
Wenn die SoCraTes nur annähernd so informativ und motivierend wie die letzte Ausgabe wird, bin ich mehr als zufrieden. :-)


***
#### Balint Pato

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am an associate of the London Software Craftsmanship Community

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://balopat.com

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ideas, inspiration, connections 


***
#### Benjamin Eberlei

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am interested in software architecture and was pointed to this event by friends that work at your sponsor Qafoo.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://whitewashing.de/

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I want to discuss and get feedbacks on my ideas regarding software architecture.


***
#### Benjamin Reitzammer

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I've been drawn to the values of Software Craftsmanship for a long time, without explicitly calling it Software Craftsmanship. So when I stumbled across the book Apprenticeship Patterns, with all it's underlying values, it resonated very strongly with me. The people and the values of Software Craftsmanship gave me concrete words for how I wanted to work.

Since then I've organized coderetreats and started the local Software Craftsmanship community in Frankfurt.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I'm [@benjamin](http://twitter.com/benjamin) on twitter.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

The feeling of having shared my experience and having learned from other participants' experience.
Another point is, to say it with Daniel Temme's words, "I'd be curious about other people's experience in getting other people to care about their work.". That's a challenge I've faced quite often already and haven't found an answer yet, that's satisfying for me.


***
#### Bernhard Findeiss

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

That's my every day job. Apart from that, I also try to participate in the community.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

www.if-blog.de/author/bf

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

The certainty, that there really are people out there for whom writing quality software really DOES matter


***
#### Carl Anders Düvel

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Mitglied der Softwerkskammer HH. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://carlduevel.net/ http://holisticon.de 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Jede Menge Anregungen und Inspiration in Sachen Software Craftsmanship. 


***
#### Christoph Pater

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Seit dem ich programmiere bin ich ständig auf der Suche nach einer einfacheren, eleganteren und wartbareren Variante der Lösung. Ich bin es leid, dass es scheinbar normal ist, Software neu zu entwickeln, weil die alte Version nicht mehr anpassbar oder zu buggy ist. Die aktuelle Ausbildungspraxis finde ich unpassend.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Blog: http://softwareLeid.de

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Neue Impulse, Kontakte, Ideen und das gute Gefühl nicht allein zu sein auf diesem Weg.


***
#### Claudius Link

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Member of the online community, believer, and beginning practitioner

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Nothing right now

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Getting to know great people or meeting them again. New ideas and practices


***
#### Conrad Müller

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Aspiring Software Craftsman

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

-

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

As many new ideas and good memories as last year


***
#### Cyrille Martraire

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I created the Paris Software Craftsmanship community

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://cyrille.martraire.com  

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Better BDD, TDD on architecture


***
#### Daniel Rosowski

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I consider myself an advanced apprentice, eager to sharpen my skills, ready to abandone what I thought might be best practices 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://github.com/drosowski http//rosowski.wordpress.com www.smartsquare.de 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Some new contacts, some ideas how to deepen the craftsmanship skills, practice 


***
#### Daniel Temme

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

it gives me hope that there are still people that care about what they do.   

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I'd like to share experiences from code retreats.    I also like to rant.    I can share some practical experiences testing in the java and javascript world.    I'd say I'd share blog posts or code but I always lack behind on all of that so it would be a somewhat empty promise. ;)  

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I'd be curious about other people's experience in getting other people to care about their work. 


***
#### David Tanzer

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am interested in the software craftsmanship movement, but have not participated in any events yet.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://davidtanzer.net

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Better ways to develop software. Lots of conversations with nice people.


***
#### Dimitry Polivaev

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Follower and admirer

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

open source mind map editor http://freeplane.org

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Friends and experiences


***
#### Dirk Eiris

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

believer

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

war stories of corporate software projects 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

a memory of some great conversations and some new ideas 


***
#### Eike Reinel

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**


**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**


**What do you want to take home from the event?**



***
#### Florian Hopf

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Trying to write code as good as possible, trying to attend Softwerkskammer meetings as regularly as possible :)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://fhopf.blogspot.com

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Motivation, a lot of new ideas


***
#### Gonçalo Silva

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Im a member of the London Software Craftsmanship community and I've been helping run a few events

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I would like to pair and maybe give a lightning talk

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

More knowledge about software, improved skills and a bunch of new friends :)


***
#### Gregor Gramlich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I try to bring the values of learning and curiosity to my colleagues in the company.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

We could run a little competition like last year's Poker-bot competition, this time with Mäxchen/Mia.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas, more energy


***
#### Hans Martin Kern

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Member of Karlsruhe Softwerkskammer, Main interests are TDD & Clean Code. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://www.spuriousthoughts.com 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ideas for in-house workshops / code retreats. 


***
#### Harald Groß

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

None at the moment

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Currently all information is just stored in my companies wiki and repositories :-(

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas. Other view to our business


***
#### Heiko Seebach

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I started an initiative called LessCode which is partially inspired by CleanCode and may somehow fit into the context of software craftsmanship

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I want to share my experiences with dynamic languages - Ruby in particular

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

new inspirations and experiences from others


***
#### Jan Ernsting

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Being an active member of the Software Craftsman community / SoCraMOB.  Continuous improvement of personal software development skills.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://github.com/janernsting

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Meeting other craftsmen and exchanging plenty of thoughts.  Getting to know my tools even better.


***
#### Jaroslaw Klose

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I was getting sick of bad written and not well crafted software. Therefore I was infected by the idea of a “good piece of work”. I want to get better skills and to meet developers with similar ideas. I am also a co-founder of SoCraMOB, a local Software Craftsmanship group.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I want to share my experiences in software development, customer work and organizing community events.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I want to meet more infected developers and discover new ideas and techniques. 

***
#### Johannes Seitz

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I like it.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Blog: http://www.printhelloworld.de  Code: https://github.com/Ookami86

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Test automation knowledge, apprenticeship ideas and contacts to kindred spirits.


***
#### Jörg Audörsch

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Qualitätsverantwortlicher im agilen Umfeld

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Erfahrungsaustausch.   Meine Erfahrung: Einführung von agilen Methoden im konservativen Umfeld (4 Jahre)

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

besseres Verständnis für QS im agilen Softwareentwicklungsprozess


***
#### Julien Meddah

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Journeyman

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

https://github.com/meddahj

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ideas, motivation, awesome experience, different views


***
#### Jürgen Bickert

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I want to create software that works the first time.  I also signed the Manifesto.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

https://github.com/simpleprogrammer

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

I expect to find ways to incrementally improve software design and to improve the way of testing.


***
#### Jürgen Wehr

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**


**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**


**What do you want to take home from the event?**



***
#### Kai de Haan

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Software developer interested in it

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

skaverat.net

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

the more the better ;)


***
#### Kim Hagedorn

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Ganz gut:)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Ich bin ein Softwareentwickler mit viel Meinung und wenig Erfahrung. Also
werde ich wohl vor allem viel zuhören und hin und wieder dumme Fragen
stellen.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich möchte vor allem neue Ansichten mitnehmen, was gute Software wirklich
ausmacht.


***
#### Kore Nordmann

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Interessiert beobachtend.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Blog: http://kore-nordmann.de & http://kore-nordmann.de/portfolio.html
Github: github.com/kore

Erfahrungen mit QA, Testing, Software-Design im Bereich von PHP (& JS)
und Webentwicklung allgemein trage ich gerne in Diskussionen oder
Vortraegen bei.

Bio:

Kore Nordmann graduated in 2010 with a degree in computer science
(University). He managed and manages different PHP open source projects,
like Arbit, PHPillow, VCS-Wrapper and others. Some of them can be found
on his website, on Ohloh or github. During the last years he presented
on national and international conferences and published several articles
and books. In 2010 he founded the Qafoo GmbH - passion for software
quality - together with Tobias Schlitt and Manuel Pichler, in which he
provides Consulting & Training aiming for better software quality.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Interesse an Qualitaetsmanagement / Testing in anderen Umgebungen (PHP &
JS QA ist unser Beruf).


***
#### Marc Philipp

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I strive to be a software craftsman every day. I helped organize the first SoCraTes camp even though I knew that I wouldn't be able participate. Therefore, I'm really looking forward to be part of it this year.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://www.marcphilipp.de/  
http://github.com/marcphilipp

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas and inspiration, get to know other community organizers, especially from different countries.


***
#### Marco Emrich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am a practitioner in software craftmanship. I prefer pragmatic approaches and clean code!     I also perform and teach tdd and bdd and love to participate in katas and code retreats.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://www.webmasters-akademie.de/blog/autoren/marco

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

interesting and opposing views to test driven development, clean code and modern practices


***
#### Markus Barchfeld

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Participated last year in Sokrates 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

nada

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

a t-shirt


***
#### Markus Gärtner

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I was around in November/December 2008  on the mailing list and helped with the principles.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

My experience with user groups, software craftsmanship, and help evolve the movement in Germany.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Lots of new contacts.


***
#### Markus Knittig

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm a freelance software developer who tries to use and promote craftsmanship. I also helped a bit organizing the first SoCraTes conference ;)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://github.com/mknittig

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New views on how to do software development and especially operations right. Met new people who share this views.


***
#### Martin Heider

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm working as an Agile Consultant, Coach and Mentor with more than ten years of Programming background. In that roleI'm convinced by the importance of Software Craftmanship and Clean Code. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

As I haven't produced productive code for a White I will bring in a beginner's mind and courage to step out of my comfort zone. It's like visiting the roots of my professional career, the origin I came from.  

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

An impression where the state of the art Software craftmanship movement stands today. A better understanding of developers today and the experience to do coding katas and dojos again. 


***
#### Martin Klose

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I'm one of the Socrates organizers and one of the Socramob founders. At Socrates 2011 I met other Software Craftsmans from my region. As we were not form the same town,  for that not able to start a community in our respective towns, we joined forces and started Socramob.org - the local Software Craftsmanship community for Münster, Osnabrück and Bielefeld. Our group has 50+ members and we have run a couple events by now. At the moment I'm helping to build the local Software Craftsmanship community in Berlin. I also like to facilitate coderetreats.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

My curiosity for new ideas, my experience with starting a local community and organizing events. 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas, inspiration and meeting other Software Craftsman.


***
#### Mashooq Badar

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

One of the organisers of the London Software Craftsmanship Community

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://mashb.wordpress.com/

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Knowledge, Ideas, Inpiration from other Participants


***
#### Michael Rotmanov

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

I am a responsible Software Developer since 2007 and try to improve myself all the time.  

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://www.github.com/leachim2k 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Skills for responsible code 


***
#### Nicole Rauch

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

It is an important part of my daily work as software developer. I want to raise the awareness on a more holistic view on software development and on quality. Apart from that, I am co-organizer of SoCraTes and co-founder of Softwerkskammer, the German Software Craftsmanship Community. 

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

My blog: http://pboop.wordpress.com 

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Anything that crosses my path: New experiences, new people, interesting stuff that ranges from purely technical to totally esoteric :-) 


***
#### Oliver Paczkowski

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Organizer and contributor at SoCraMOB

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

twitter.com/gadeshot

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

meeting great people and having fabulous discussions like 2011


***
#### Pierluigi Pugliese

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

As an agile coach supporting organisations implementing agile I believe software craftsmanship is a key aspect in delivering quality software. While I'm too rusty in coding to be a craftsmanship myself, I can at least help the community to grow.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

I will be moderating the open space and I will do my best to support an intense flow of communication among the participants. I would also like to discuss what benefit could a software craftsmanship get from individual or team coaching, presenting a few ideas I have about this topic.

When I'm not at conferences, I am coaching teams and companies who want to introduce agile software development.

For more information: http://www.connexxo.com, http://blog.connexxo.com

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

New ideas and new developments in the software craftsmanship community, new friends.

***
#### Roland Jülich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Software Craftsmanship ist aus meiner Sicht der "Oberbegriff" für die Werte, Prinzipien und Methoden professioneller Softwareentwicklung mit dem Ziel kontinuierlich, qualitativ hochwertige Software zu bauen und zu liefern. Die dazu nötigen Skills werden in der Regel erst durch mehrjährige Praxiserfahrung erworben. Vorraussetzung ist allerdings die stetige Bereitschaft sich kritisch mit der eigenen Arbeit auseinanderzusetzen (auch durch Feedback von anderen), sie zu verbessern, sich ständig weiterzubilden und elementare Techniken zu üben.

Vor diesem Hintergrund sehe ich mich als angehenden Software Craftsman, der für die Prinzipien und Werte in ihrer Vielschichtigkeit sensibilisiert ist und gegenwärtig daran arbeitet seine  Methodik auf- und auszubauen um sie in die tägliche Entwicklungsarbeit zu integrieren. Das ist gar nicht immer so einfach... Da ich in dem Zusammenhang stets auf der Suche nach inspirierenden Ideen, Gesprächen und Mentoren bin, möchte ich mit der "Softwerkskammer Hamburg" als Community of Practice, mir und allen die ähnlich denken ein Forum zum gegenseitigen Austausch geben. Ich freue mich immer wenn ich andere dafür begeistern kann sich mit auf diese Reise zu begeben. ;)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Roland Jülich, Consultant bei der Holisticon AG in Hamburg. Ich bin als Berater und Coach im Geschäftsfeld Architektur mit dem Schwerpunkt agiler Entwicklungsmethoden in verschiedenen Projekten im JEE Umfeld tätig. Persönliche Interessen und Schwerpunkte liegen auf Themen wie Clean Code, Test Driven Development und Automatisierung von Akzeptanztests speziell im Bereich der RIA- und Rich-Client-Entwicklung.

Im Bereich akzeptanztestgetriebener Entwicklung könnte ich bei Interesse das Thema Behavior Driven Development mit Cucumber und Selenium im Java Umfeld vorstellen. Als Format wäre sowohl ein klassischer Vortrag aber auch ein Workshop denkbar. Auf jeden Fall suche ich den Austausch mit anderen im Rahmen des Open Space.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Auf jeden Fall fände ich Anregungen und Inspirationen von anderen Craftsman wie bspw. zur Durchführung von Workshops oder Coding Dojos um andere für das Thema zu begeistern als extrem nützlich. Darüberhinaus möchte ich mich bei der Gelegenheit auch mal mit den anderen Softwerkskammer Moderatoren über mögliche Veranstaltungsformate und Inhalte unterhalten.

#### Andreas Simon

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Ich bin gerne stolz auf meine Arbeit. Ich bin froh, wenn ich stabilen, wartbaren, gut lesbaren Code produziert habe. Ich habe generell einen sehr hohen Anspruch an meine Arbeit.
Ich lerne andauernd und gerne mehr über TDD, OO Design und agile Methoden. Ich gebe auch gerne mein Wissen - z.B. im Rahmen von Code Retreats - an jüngere Entwickler weiter.
Am Ende der letzten SoCraTes habe ich mich mit Markus Gärtner, Martin Klose und Oliver Paczkowski zusammengetan, um die Regionalgruppe SoCraMOB in der Region Münster, Osnabrück, Bielefeld ins Leben zu rufen. Wir haben mittlerweile zwei ganztägige Open Spaces und drei Code Retreats veranstaltet. Unsere Mitgliederzahl wächst kontinuierlich.

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

http://andreas-simon.blogspot.com  
https://github.com/andreassimon  
Ich entwickle Web-Anwendungen mit Java und Ruby.
Meine Stärken liegen im Strukturieren und Mustersuchen. Ich habe zu vielen Bereichen eine klare Meinung und verfechte sie gerne in angeregten Diskussionen.

Für unsere SC Community habe ich einen Überblick über die Geschichte / Wurzeln von Software Craftsmanship zusammengestellt. Gerne würde ich den Vortrag auch bei der SoCraTes anbieten.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Ich freue mich darauf, einige "Meister" unseres Faches zu treffen und von ihnen zu lernen.
Insbesondere interessiert mich, wie andere Craftsmen mit Legacy Code umgehen. Außerdem würde ich gerne mehr über Domain-Driven Design lernen: wie wenden andere Teilnehmer die Ideen von DDD in ihren Projekten an?
Ich würde mich auch gerne mit den Organisatoren anderer Communities austauschen, welche Veranstaltungsformate sie durchgeführt haben und wie das Feedback war.
Wenn die SoCraTes nur annähernd so informativ und motivierend wie die letzte Ausgabe wird, bin ich mehr als zufrieden. :-)

Bio:

Kore Nordmann graduated in 2010 with a degree in computer science
(University). He managed and manages different PHP open source projects,
like Arbit, PHPillow, VCS-Wrapper and others. Some of them can be found
on his website, on Ohloh or github. During the last years he presented
on national and international conferences and published several articles
and books. In 2010 he founded the Qafoo GmbH - passion for software
quality - together with Tobias Schlitt and Manuel Pichler, in which he
provides Consulting & Training aiming for better software quality.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Interesse an Qualitaetsmanagement / Testing in anderen Umgebungen (PHP &
JS QA ist unser Beruf).

***
#### Roland Jülich

**What is your relation to Software Craftsmanship?**

Software Craftsmanship ist aus meiner Sicht der "Oberbegriff" für die Werte, Prinzipien und Methoden professioneller Softwareentwicklung mit dem Ziel kontinuierlich, qualitativ hochwertige Software zu bauen und zu liefern. Die dazu nötigen Skills werden in der Regel erst durch mehrjährige Praxiserfahrung erworben. Vorraussetzung ist allerdings die stetige Bereitschaft sich kritisch mit der eigenen Arbeit auseinanderzusetzen (auch durch Feedback von anderen), sie zu verbessern, sich ständig weiterzubilden und elementare Techniken zu üben.

Vor diesem Hintergrund sehe ich mich als angehenden Software Craftsman, der für die Prinzipien und Werte in ihrer Vielschichtigkeit sensibilisiert ist und gegenwärtig daran arbeitet seine  Methodik auf- und auszubauen um sie in die tägliche Entwicklungsarbeit zu integrieren. Das ist gar nicht immer so einfach... Da ich in dem Zusammenhang stets auf der Suche nach inspirierenden Ideen, Gesprächen und Mentoren bin, möchte ich mit der "Softwerkskammer Hamburg" als Community of Practice, mir und allen die ähnlich denken ein Forum zum gegenseitigen Austausch geben. Ich freue mich immer wenn ich andere dafür begeistern kann sich mit auf diese Reise zu begeben. ;)

**What do you want to share with the other participants? This can e.g. be your blog or your code repository.**

Roland Jülich, Consultant bei der Holisticon AG in Hamburg. Ich bin als Berater und Coach im Geschäftsfeld Architektur mit dem Schwerpunkt agiler Entwicklungsmethoden in verschiedenen Projekten im JEE Umfeld tätig. Persönliche Interessen und Schwerpunkte liegen auf Themen wie Clean Code, Test Driven Development und Automatisierung von Akzeptanztests speziell im Bereich der RIA- und Rich-Client-Entwicklung.

Im Bereich akzeptanztestgetriebener Entwicklung könnte ich bei Interesse das Thema Behavior Driven Development mit Cucumber und Selenium im Java Umfeld vorstellen. Als Format wäre sowohl ein klassischer Vortrag aber auch ein Workshop denkbar. Auf jeden Fall suche ich den Austausch mit anderen im Rahmen des Open Space.

**What do you want to take home from the event?**

Auf jeden Fall fände ich Anregungen und Inspirationen von anderen Craftsman wie bspw. zur Durchführung von Workshops oder Coding Dojos um andere für das Thema zu begeistern als extrem nützlich. Darüberhinaus möchte ich mich bei der Gelegenheit auch mal mit den anderen Softwerkskammer Moderatoren über mögliche Veranstaltungsformate und Inhalte unterhalten.

This page is used to generate and collect ideas for sessions to be held at SoCraTes 2012. In addition, participants interested in hosting a session can find support of like-minded people to prepare and facilitate the session together.

## How does it work?

*Adding a session*: If you have a session idea please grab the Wiki source code of the template from below, copy it, and add your session to the list at the bottom.   
*Expressing interest in a session*: If you are interested in a session on the list, please add your name to the list of interested people of this session. Please also think about how you could contribute and put your contribution in parentheses after your name.



---

#### Session Title

Session Description ...

*Session host:* YOUR NAME HERE   
*Interested*: ...

## Session Ideas

*Session host:* Johannes S. (@Ookami86) / Christoph Pater (@christophpater)   
*Interested*: ...

---

#### Intro to Smalltalk

A close look at Smalltalk (the programming language, that is ;-)

*Session host:* Andreas Simon, Andreas Leidig  
*Interested*: Nicole Rauch, Marc Philipp

---

#### Architectural Katas

I find Ted Neward's [Architectural Katas](http://www.architecturalkatas.com/) idea quite intriguing, and would like to try (at least) one with other participants. I haven't done an Architectural Kata yet, so it's not a "I share experience with you" session, but rather a "let's work out the experience together" session.

*Session host:* Benjamin Reitzammer  
*Interested*: Christoph Pater, Marc Philipp
